Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Data Reduction for Networked Inference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technological advances in devices, computing, communication, and networking have allowed the development and deployment of networked sensing systems of varying scales with diverse applications. The voluminous data collected in these networked systems, however, present some unique challenges. Ensuring that useful data be available at the right location in a timely fashion is difficult in a large scale network because of various limitations inherent in such systems. In addition, the collected data in its raw form often lacks clarity for making an informed decision. The primary goal of the project is to develop theory and methodology that allow the raw data to be reduced to the extent such that 1) their transmission to the desired destination is compliant to the system limitation, and 2) there is no loss of information with respect to the mission of the networked system.

The project pursues a comprehensive treatment of data reduction in such inference networks and aims to develop the sufficiency principle and related theory and methods to overcome these challenges. Intimate connection between data reduction for inference and data compression for transmission is exploited and expanded in the network setting. New interpretations using the sufficiency principle for some classical multi-terminal source coding problems will be developed; they provide a new venue for the exploration of the connection between statistics and information theory. The development of theory and methods that guide data reduction in a networked inference system also has the potential to unify existing works that are tailored toward specific inference problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Distilling useful information from voluminous data that are coming from distributed sources is an enormous challenge. Progresses toward overcoming such a challenge has broad implications on numerous emerging applications that involve deluge of data arising from distributed and heterogeneous sources. 

This project leverage recent breakthroughs in multiple disciplines, including statistical inference and learning, information theory, and network science to tackle this challenge. Classical sufficiency principle, which has been a cornerstone of diverse statistical inference framework is expanded in a distributed setting where new challenges have been identified and addressed. Important breakthroughs have been obtained including characterizing the limiting behavior when the networks scale for various inference problems. A total of seven journal papers (all of them IEEE journals) have been published or accepted with three more to be under review or under preparation.

The research project has greatly advanced the understanding of the basic science in inference over networks. A new graduate course (ELE853 Network Information Theory - Source Coding) was offered in the Fall of 2012 that include materials directly relevant to or as a result of the research project. The active involvement of graduate students in the project has been an integral part of the project. A total of six doctoral students have been supported under or worked on problems related to this project. Five of them have since graduated, including three who are female graduate students. All except one are working on STEM related areas.
